ration.translation[0].definitions[0].def: a fixed amount of something that people are allowed to have when there is not enough, for example during a war
ration.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: a coal ration of 4 kg a month
Even wool was on ration in the war.
ration.translation[0].definitions[1].def: an amount of something that you think is reasonable or normal
ration.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: holidaymakers who like a generous ration of open-air activity
ration.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to control the supply of something because there is not enough
ration.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Fuel was rationed during the war.
ration.translation[1].definitions[0].not: Ration is usually passive in this meaning
ration.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to allow someone only a small amount of something
ration.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: the need to ration health care resources
He rationed himself to 4 cigarettes a day.
I try to ration the childrenâ€™s television viewing to an hour a day.
ration.translation[2].definitions[0].def: a fixed amount of something such as food or petrol that you are allowed to have when there is not much available
ration.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: Food is in short supply and the country has apparently tightened rations  (=made less available to each person).
ration.translation[3].definitions[0].def: to control the supply of something such as food or petrol by allowing people to have only a fixed amount of it
ration.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: Cuba has rationed food for four decades, largely because of the U.S. embargo.
ration.translation[3].definitions[1].def: to allow someone to have only a small amount of something, or less than they would like, because there is not enough
ration.translation[3].definitions[1].exa: The company rationed people to 200 new shares each.
